Award.AwardTitle: CREST Center for Water and the Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of New Mexico CREST Center for Water and the Environment will investigate technological solutions to problems with water and the environment, and will focus on water problems in arid environments and in times of drought, including those associated with deteriorating watersheds, climate change, water needs for energy development, and technologies to address these challenges. These issues are critical to the Southwestern U.S. but also have global importance. This center will attract underrepresented minorities into STEM careers. Recruitment, retention, and graduation of underrepresented minorities are an integral feature of the Center. Innovative programs in this Center will include construction of a water technology demonstration trailer with hands-on water activities for K-12 students, a water competition, recruiting at regional minority-serving colleges and junior colleges, as well as mentoring and tutoring programs. The research component is organized around four topics: watershed processes, water treatment technologies, water/energy interactions, and research integration. The Watershed Subproject focuses on how watershed management affects hydrologic processes, ecosystem services, and the consequent quantity and quality of water available to downstream users. The Treatment Technology Subproject investigates technologies for the removal of nutrients, trace pollutants, and emerging contaminants to minimize anthropogenic impacts to water supplies and maximize use of impaired and low-quality waters for different uses. The Water/Energy Subproject examines water resource impacts from oil, gas, and uranium development and identifies strategies to minimize them. These three topics are intrinsically related because of the hydrologic connection of surface and ground water resources, and the need to protect, conserve, and put every drop to beneficial use. These relationships will be investigated in the fourth topic, the Research Integration Subproject. This topic will develop strategies to support decision-making processes by considering uncertainty, social, economic, policy and legal factors.

Intellectual Merit:
This Center will generate significant new knowledge about the management and treatment of water in arid and semi-arid environments. It will have regional and global consequences as climate change and population growth cause a decrease in water supplies. Greater understanding of the impacts of historical watershed management practices and the effect of improved watershed management strategies will increase runoff and improve quality. Improved biological and physical-chemical treatment technologies allow improvements in quality and reductions in cost and energy that will permit use and/or reuse of low quality water. Development of energy resources is important to the economy but impacts water resources. New technologies will reduce these impacts and decrease the costs. Simultaneous consideration of the social, economic, and cultural consequences of watersheds, treatment, and energy development is critical to permit community involvement in management decisions.

Broader Impacts:
This Center will focus on the recruitment, training, and graduation of underrepresented minority students. These activities will create a pipeline of new STEM professionals to address the water problems of the future. This Center will have beneficial impacts on a global scale by developing technologies and strategies for managing water in arid regions. It will produce regional benefits by increasing supplies through improved watershed management strategies. It will facilitate economic development of energy resources by minimizing water resource impacts. The research results will be disseminated broadly through a website, peer-reviewed technical literature, national conference presentations, and in venues and formats accessible to water professionals to improve water management decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Phase I grant from the NSF CREST program to the University of New Mexico Center for Water and the Environment has led to a transformation in water-focused research at UNM. The 5 years of support allowed us to generate and disseminate timely knowledge to understand and mitigate problems with water resource quantity and quality, and develop technological solutions to those problems, particularly with respect to our 4 themes: (1) impacts of watershed management on hydrologic and ecosystem processes, (2) innovative water and wastewater treatment technologies to protect water quality and public health, (3) environmental impacts of resource extraction for energy production, and (4) decision-making to address water quality and quantity issues.

Our research in the watershed theme demonstrated that sediment levels, discharge, and water chemistry in headwater streams draining burned landscapes take between one to several years to return to pre-fire conditions. We found that large rivers can process carbon and nutrients at rates similar to those observed in headwater streams, which suggests that they should be integrated in watershed management plans and regional-to-global assessments of biogeochemical cycles.

In the treatment technology theme, our research revealed features of biofilm support media that improve nutrient removal and decrease energy consumption, resulting in better wastewater treatment. We demonstrated the potential for algae to treat wastewater, which may be suitable for biofuel production, including demonstrating the potential for algae to treat saline wastewaters from oil and gas production. We demonstrated that membrane distillation is highly efficient (nearly 100%) at removing salinity and organic carbon from wastewater effluent, but pore wetting and rapid fouling may prevent full-scale application of this technology for potable reuse. We elucidated several aspects of silica removal to prevent membrane fouling during desalination of brackish groundwater, including sorption mechanisms, appropriate water chemistry conditions, and loading rates.

Within the water/energy theme, we developed a model of regional water/energy interactions and used it to demonstrate the extent to which future mining operations in New Mexico could decrease the groundwater resources available for municipal use. We showed that poor aquifer flow conditions reduce remediation effectiveness after in-situ leach mining. We identified dissolution of uranium and vanadium mineral phases and seasonal flow conditions as key factors in the transport of co-occurring metals in sites contaminated by mining waste in Navajo and other tribal lands. Finally, we quantified energy requirements for fresh and produced water management in oil and gas production, finding that produced water may be a viable replacement for freshwater used for fracking in the Permian Basin, which can help preserve freshwater for municipal and agricultural uses.

The decision-making theme resulted in the development of a decision support model to evaluate alternatives for flood control following wildfires that demonstrated that minimizing flood risks is as dependent on stakeholder input as it is on technical aspects. We determined that the public in inland areas is more knowledgeable of water resource issues and accepting of potable reuse than populations in large coastal communities, which sets arid inland regions as strategic hot-spots to lead a national-scale implementation of direct potable reuse programs.

In addition to the research outcomes, the CREST CWE developed innovative hands-on outreach activities that have been presented to thousands of participants during visits to local K-12 schools, public events, and professional conferences. The hands-on activities were developed and built by our students, and delivered by faculty, post-docs, and students funded through the CWE. We developed and taught a dual-credit (i.e., simultaneous high school and college credit) class about water resources and careers in STEM at a local school with high Hispanic attendance, and we sponsored an annual water conference that connected regional leaders and newcomers about water issues.

We maintained a strong focus on providing educational and research opportunities to underrepresented minorities; of the nearly 110 participants that received research funding, 73% were underrepresented minorities. Among underrepresented groups in STEM, the breakdown of funded participants was 38% Hispanic, 11% Native American, and 57% female.

In alignment with a key goal of the CREST program, the CREST Phase I grant improved institutional capacity for water-related research at UNM with targeted investments that expanded the research infrastructure. New laboratory and field instruments and equipment provided students with new capabilities and faculty with the resources to pursue extramural funding. The expanded research capacity led to additional investments in human resources; the CWE has hired a full-time environmental engineering laboratory manager and a research professor to manage the hydraulics laboratory. The expanded research capacity led to over 100 proposals for external funding. The research expenditures associated with the entire center were about $3.0 million in the most recent fiscal year. These investments have increased the quantity, quality, visibility, and recognition of water-related research at UNM.
